t: Proverbs 20
Wine*pn is*i a mocker, Strong*ld drink is*i a brawler, And*ld whoever is led astray by it is not wise.
The*ln wrath of a king is*i like the roaring of a lion; Whoever*ild provokes him to anger sins against*i his own life.
It*iln is*i honorable for a man to stop striving, Since*ld any fool can start a quarrel.
The*ln lazy man*i will not plow because of winter; He*ld will beg during harvest and have*i nothing.
Counsel*ln in the heart of man is*i like*i deep water, But*ld a man of understanding will draw it out.
Most*ln men will proclaim each his own goodness, But*ld who can find a faithful man?
The*ln righteous man*i walks in his integrity; His*ld children are*i blessed after him.
A*ln king who sits on the throne of judgment Scatters*ld all evil with his eyes.
Who*ln can say, “I have made my heart clean, I*ld am pure from my sin”?
Diverse*ln weights and*i diverse measures, They*ld are*i both alike, an abomination to the Lord.*s
Even*ln a child is known by his deeds, Whether*ld what he does is*i pure and right.
The*ln hearing ear and the seeing eye, The*ld Lord*s has made them both.
Do*ln not love sleep, lest you come to poverty; Open*ld your eyes, and*i you will be satisfied with bread.
“It*iln is*i good for nothing,” cries the buyer; But*ld when he has gone his way, then he boasts.
There*ln is gold and a multitude of rubies, But*ld the lips of knowledge are*i a precious jewel.
Take*ln the garment of one who is surety for*i a stranger, And*ld hold it as a pledge when*i it*i is for a seductress.
Bread*ln gained by deceit is*i sweet to a man, But*ld afterward his mouth will be filled with gravel.
Plans*ln are established by counsel; By*ld wise counsel wage war.
He*ln who goes about as*i a talebearer reveals secrets; Therefore*ld do not associate with one who flatters with his lips.
Whoever*ln curses his father or his mother, His*ld lamp will be put out in deep darkness.
An*ln inheritance gained hastily at the beginning Will*ld not be blessed at the end.
Do*ln not say, “I will recompense evil”; Wait*ld for the Lord,*s and He will save you.
Diverse*ln weights are*i an abomination to the Lord,*s And*ld dishonest scales are*i not good.
A*ln man’s steps are*i of the Lord;*s How*ld then can a man understand his own way?
It*iln is*i a snare for a man to devote rashly something*i as*i holy, And*ld afterward to reconsider his*i vows.
A*ld wise king sifts out the wicked, And*ld brings the threshing wheel over them.
The*ln spirit of a man is*i the lamp of the Lord,*s Searching*ld all the inner depths of his heart.
Mercy*ln and truth preserve the king, And*ld by lovingkindness he upholds his throne.
The*ln glory of young men is*i their strength, And*ld the splendor of old men is*i their gray head.
Blows*ln that hurt cleanse away evil, As*ld do*i stripes the inner depths of the heart.
